column4: erm, is it possible to resize a portion of my hardisk which is curretnly formatted with ntfs for ubuntu?

none of the available linux filesystem types can be natively used by windows; however, if you use ext3, you can install a driver in windows to access it
but, i think the installer doesn't have that...  TO:tiekyl, yes, i want to try ubuntu without sacrificing my files or windows
that's simple, all you have to do is change a line in menu.lst
change "default 0" to the number that windows is; the file is located in /boot/grub/
you must use sudo, as it requires root permission
the file is very well commented and should explain itself quite clearly
editing the file requires root access. I suggest you do the following:
open a terminal (applicatoins - accessories - terminal), and type "gksudo gedit /boot/grub/menu.lst"
then enter your password, edit the file, and save it
yes, there are two options. You can either take ownership, or grant permissions to everyone on the locations
to change permissions, use the chmod command. to change owners, use the chown command. the man pages for each should be very descriptive
